The Integrating factor

The equation\[x^2{\mathrm{d}y\over \mathrm{d}x}+3x\ y=x^3\] is not exact. However, if we multiply it by \(x\) we obtain the equation \[ x^3{\mathrm{d}y\over \mathrm{d}x}+3x^2y=x^4.\] This can be re-written as \[ {\mathrm{d}\over \mathrm{d}x} (x^3y)=x^4\] which is an exact equation with solution \[ x^3y=\int x^4 \,\mathrm{d}x\] so \[x^3y={1\over 5}x^5+C\] and hence \[ y={1\over 5}x^2+{C\over x^3}.\] The function by which we multiplied the given differential equation in order to make it exact is called an integrating factor. In this example the integrating factor is simply \(x\).
